Copenhagen Airport is a compact airport with 3 terminals for check-in, but with a common post-security departure and transfer area, thus making transfers very smooth. In 2013, Copenhagen Airport handled 24,1 million passengers.

The airport opened in 1925 and became hub of Scandinavian Airlines (SAS) upon its establishment in 1946. It has been growing ever since, with the current terminal 2 opening in 1960 and terminal 3 in 1998. After the opening of the Øresund Bridge to

, the airport has also been the primary airport for the southern Sweden.

The airport recently published an expansion plan, proposing to handle 40 million passengers a year.
For check-in, Copenhagen Airport has three terminals:

value: member airlines as well as Air Serbia, BMI Regional, Estonian Air, Icelandair, Next Jet and Widerøe.

Terminals 2 and 3 are in the vicinity of the railway and metro stations, while terminal 1 is connected by a free airport bus.

Terminal 1 has it's own security facilities, while terminals 2 and 3 share the airport's major security facility. In 2013, Copenhagen Airport was awarded World’s Best Airport Security Processing by Skytrax.

After passing security or arriving for a connection flight, you are in one large departure area, with access for all gates. The gates can be separated in the following sections, sorted from west to east:

value: "The domestic yard", typical used for small flights for domestic departures.

"CPH Go", used for low-cost departures for international destinations inside the

No gate is located more than 33 minutes walk from each other.
All international arrivals exits to Terminal 3. All domestic arrivals exits to Terminal 1.
Copenhagen Airport is adjacent to the Øresund Motorway (route E20), which connects

via the Øresund Bridge. It is a toll bridge. As of March 2014, the price for crossing in a car is DKK 335.00. From Malmö, the rest of Sweden is connected by motorways.

Most parts of Denmark is connected to the motorway network.

The airports has several parking facilities, with those near the terminals very expensive, and those far away somewhat cheaper. The far parking areas has a free bus connection to the terminals.

. The frequent Øresund trains between Copenhagen and Malmö continues in Denmark to
and in Sweden to a number of destinations in

.

The travel time to Copenhagen Central Station is 12 minutes, and 20 minutes to Malmö Central Station.
In terminal 3, the terminus of Copenhagen Metro line M2 is located (
). The metro is very frequent and runs to Vanløse via the central Copenhagen interchange station

.

The travel time to Nørreport Station is 15 minutes.

For prices, see

The bus terminal is located outside of terminal 2. The airport is only served by a few local buses (lines 5A, 35 and 36), which are charged in the same way as the metro and local trains.

The airport has also coach connections to
Taxis are located just outside the terminals.

A free airport bus connects the terminals and the parking areas every 15 minute (though, at night every 20 minute).

After passing security, no gate is more than a 33 minute walk away.
The airport has several lounge facilities, a large shopping centre, restaurants etc.
In the airport, several restaurants, bars and cafes are located.

Copenhagen Airport has a large number of shops in the international departure area, including fashion, living, electronics, toy, and souvenir stores.
The whole airport has WiFi coverage.
The airport has a post-security prayer room.
